facts.text: Appeals arise from judgment and order dated 29th August 1972 of Madhya Pradesh High Court at Jabalpur in Misc. Petitions Nos. 191 of 1968, 30 of 1970, 63 and 64 of 1972.
Appellants challenged constitutional validity of section 8(2)(b) of Central Sales Tax Act, 1956 before High Court, which upheld the provisions.
Appeals preferred on certificate under Article 133(1)(c) of Constitution.
Section 8(1) provides 3% tax on inter-State sales to Government or registered dealers (with declarations).
Section 8(2)(a): For declared goods not under s.8(1), tax at rate applicable inside appropriate State.
Section 8(2)(b): For other goods not under s.8(1), tax at 10% or State rate, whichever higher.
High Court answered in negative that s.8(2)(b) suffers from excessive delegation.

legal_issues.text: Whether provisions of section 8(2)(b) of Central Sales Tax Act, 1956 suffer from vice of excessive delegation of legislative power.

petitioner_arguments.text: Fixation of rate of tax is legislative function; Parliament under s.8(2)(b) has not fixed rate but adopted higher State rate exceeding 10%, abdicating legislative function.
Parliament delegated to State legislatures without guidance.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: B. Shama Rao v. Union Territory of Pondicherry

respondent_arguments.text: Provision prevents evasion of central sales tax by discouraging sales to unregistered dealers.

court_reasoning.text: Clear legislative policy in s.8(2)(b): tax at 10% if State rate lower, or State rate if higher, to deter inter-State sales to unregistered dealers and prevent evasion.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Object is to ensure central sales tax not less than local sales tax.

court_reasoning.text: Impossible for Parliament to fix maximum rate as State rates vary and change; must tack to local rate exceeding 10%.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No abdication; policy to plug evasion loopholes.

court_reasoning.text: Distinguishes B. Shama Rao: no total surrender to another legislature; here Parliament adopts local rate for own policy in CST Act.
court_reasoning.key_observation: CST revenue assigned to States under Art.269.

court_reasoning.text: Reviews precedents: legislature must lay down policy/standard before delegating; here policy enunciated sufficiently.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Fixing rates can be delegated with guidance.

court_reasoning.text: Mathew J. separate opinion: No delegation to States; Parliament adopts State rates without abdication; reviews global precedents affirming delegation necessity.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Delegation essential for modern governance; no abdication here.

holdings.text: Section 8(2)(b) of Central Sales Tax Act does not suffer from excessive delegation or abdication of legislative power.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Madras v. N. K. Nataraja Mudaliar
precedents_cited.relevance: Upholds s.8(2)(b) to prevent evasion; negligible impact on inter-State trade.

precedents_cited.case_name: B. Shama Rao v. Union Territory of Pondicherry
precedents_cited.relevance: Total surrender unlike here; Pondicherry adopted/amended Madras Act blindly.

precedents_cited.case_name: Corporation of Calcutta v. Liberty Cinema
precedents_cited.relevance: Fixing rates may be delegated to non-legislative body with guidance.

precedents_cited.case_name: Municipal Corporation of Delhi v. Birla Cotton Spinning and Weaving Mills
precedents_cited.relevance: Delegation valid if policy laid down; nature of delegate matters.

precedents_cited.case_name: Devi Das Gopal Krishnan v. State of Punjab
precedents_cited.relevance: Essential function is policy determination; details delegable.
No unlimited delegation; must retain essential functions.

precedents_cited.case_name: Harishankar Bagla v. State of Madhya Pradesh
Pandit Banarsi Das v. State of Madhya Pradesh
Municipal Board Hapur v. Raghuvendra Kripal
precedents_cited.relevance: Delegation to municipalities with safeguards valid.

precedents_cited.case_name: Sita Ram Bishambhar Dayal v. State of U.P.

precedents_cited.relevance: Delegation valid if control retained; framework provided.

statutes_cited.name: Central Sales Tax Act, 1956
statutes_cited.relevance: Tax rates for inter-State sales; challenged for delegation in rate fixation.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Certificate for appeal; legislative powers; assignment of CST revenue.

outcome.summary: Appeals dismissed holding s.8(2)(b) valid, no excessive delegation; policy to prevent tax evasion clearly laid down.
outcome.costs: Dismissed with costs. One hearing fee.

key_quotes.text: "The policy of the law in this respect is that in case the rate of local sales tax be less than 10 per cent... the dealer... should pay central sales tax at the rate of 10 per cent. If... more than 10 per cent, ... the rate of the central sales tax shall also be the same."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "Section 8(2)(b) of the Act has plainly been enacted with a view to prevent evasion of the payment of the central sales tax."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "The legislature must retain in its own hands the essential legislative functions and what can be delegated is the task of subordinate legislation necessary for implementing the purposes and objects of the Act."
key_quotes.speaker: court
